introduction.sublineText: or why Avatar will see 4 sequels and John Carter none
introduction.text:
Films cost money.
However, they hope to make that money back and often do. When they do, it can be a lot and when they don’t it can be bitter. Sometimes they don’t expect to make money but they unexpectadly do. They often consume ridiculous amounts of effort, people and skill; they scream and shout to get into the public sphere which in turn decides their rise or fall. Films are bets on human taste and they ought to entertain to succeed. It's the fickle relationship between business interests and public taste that can make it joyous or painful to look at films and their money-harvest. Sizeable investments can in fact accrue mountains of gold while sometimes money just evaporates in front of empty screens. This visual story shows the ups and downs (or rather rights and lefts) of the film business, portraying a handful of stories, surprises and failures. Just keep on scrolling... (data from here, here and here)

main.text: The biggest budgets

First let’s look at the big fish.
Up there are the 20 films with the biggest production budgets ever recorded.

Avatar is already a mature guest in this list being released in 2009. But it’s earned its top spot with a whopping $425 million budget. Exactly 6 years later on the day (the 18th of December that is) Star Wars’ The Force Awakens tried hard but stays significantly behind with a mere $306 million production budget. An interesting feature for us to watch will be John Carter (previously known as John Carter of Mars) checking in at $280 million as the 6th biggest production so far.

In general you might notice that all films are what one would call Action or its close friend Adventure — apart from Tangled, the only Animation that cost the indecent sum of $260 million.
Play around with above genre buttons to see which films are what...

Now let’s see what they managed to get in.

First from North American screenings
it's including United States, Canada, Puerto Rico and Guam. For brevity I shall call these revenues 'US revenues' - apologies, rather rude but much shorter

Keeping the production budget on screen in blue, we can already see how some films lost all worry-lines after just counting the US revenue. Avatar, Star Wars, Avengers and some others could’ve just packed up to lay back and stay at home, while others were surely hoping for more international dollars.

Let's sort by US revenue.

Star Wars looks a hopeful winner raking in more than double its costs. Avatar didn't quite get that far at home. But much more importantly our animated friend Tangled didn’t quite break even in the US while John Carter can't have been very pleased with its US performance.
Now please brace yourselves and let's lift our eyes up towards Avatar — and enjoy the ride bringing in the overall, total and full worldwide box-office revenues.

Overall Avatar made a mind boggling $2.78 billion. Stacking the money would lift you up 303 km or 189 miles above sea-level (it would apparently). Less than a marathon from the International Space Station 340 km away. Anyhow. Star Wars is pretty jaw-dropping as well, but you would need to run a little further to the ISS (130 km).

In other news (while sorting by worldwide revenue) we’re happy Tangled as our lonesome premium animation made it comfortably to the safe zone, while it seems John Carter actually just got its money worth. However — the production budget doesn’t show the marketing cost, which is pretty much exactly what it lost: around $150-200 million. Hurty. Wouldn’t quite make it to Mars.

So far this only shows the mass attractiveness. But how much in tune are film ratings with the revenue? Let’s have a look at 2 of them…

The size and saturation of these bubbles show the IMDb rating (the length of of these lollipops still show worldwide revenue, but we sorted by IMDb ratings). IMDb ratings are close to the masses (of at least film-aficionados) as every registered IMDb user can vote. You can hover over the circles to get more info. Not that much surprises here. Pirates of the Caribbean wasn’t really as much loved as the income suggested and — well — John Carter and The Lone Ranger weren’t exactly embraced by the public either.

Rotten Tomatoes is further away from the populace and closer to the distinguished film taste, one would hope, as only people who earn their money with going to the cinema are allowed to elaborate and cast their votes from 1 (dismal) to 10 (blissful). There are some disconnects between IMDb and Rotten Tomatoes like Superman Returns, but in general it’s interesting to see how the patterns are more or less matching, yet more pronounced at Rotten Tomatoes. Much more variation in the data but both distributions follow the money.

In fact, let's have a look...

Here's a scatterplot putting the 2 in relation to each other. And indeed, they move alongside each other more or less. See the 5 blinking bubbles? They indicate films with significantly lower ratings than the average of IMDb and/or Rotten Tomatoes ratings. Orange blink means lower than average, green means higher than average and yellow means IMDb and Rotten Tomatoes ratings differ significantly more than their average discrepency. Science. Pah. Let's move on...
The most profitable films
Now, let’s keep on the road of success, accelerating our trip a little. More surprises to come, though ! Let’s look at the top 20 most profitable films.

If I wanted to make a film with a big budget, I’d surely try Action as a Genre. If I wanted to make a profitable film, I’d probably go for an Animation. Frozen, Minions, Despicable Me, The Lion King — all there.

Where are the US bubbles off to?

All eyes to the right.

The worldwide revenue?

…onwards.
this is also sorted by worldwide revenues

Avatar dwarves the rest but Frozen would make it quite far on their tower of dollars.

The ratings (IMDb in this case) are all relatively decent with the Twilight Saga probably choosing to count the money rather than caring about their dismal ratings.
lollipop length shows worldwide revenue - bubble size and saturation show IMDb rating

Both Twilight films get significantly worse ratings from the generally agreeing IMDb and Rotten Tomatoes critics. However, 2 films are blinking in yellow, meaning IMDb and Rotten Tomatoes have some beef here. Both, Pirates and Transformers have been rated much higher on IMDb than on Rotten Tomatoes.
Pretty large and red (purple?) for IMDb coloured and sized bubbles...

...rather small and white for Rotten Tomatoes coloured/sized bubbles.

which we shall now stick back on our lollipops
The biggest money losers
Now let’s look at the bottom of the pile. Not necessarily in terms of quality (we’ll see…) but in terms of money made. Here are the top 20 money losers.
Here are their production budgets…
…and their US gross moving to the shameful left. Can the worldwide revenue help?

Not in many cases. As you can see some worldwide revenues in fact supersede the production budgets but the marketing costs are not party to this data, so you have to trust me (and the numbers) that we’re indeed seeing losses for each film above. As a mild disclaimer it should further be mentioned that Studios don't exactly spell out their Profit & Loss sheets — introducing a level of uncertainty.

So what genre should I opt for in case I wanted to make sure to lose as much money as possible? This is a little harder. I’m inclined to go Sci-Fi/Fantasy? At least I should not let much reality into my film. John Carter (I won’t mention him again), Green Lantern, Jack the Giant Slayer, Jupiter Ascending, Gods of Egypt (who doesn't like mythological action, though?) etc. Should be the safe choice…

Hugo is a sad guest here as it's undoubtedly one of the better films in this bitter list but some directors should probably be decoupled from money pressures.

Bubbles showing Rotten Tomatoes ratings, which the data is also sortedby
The low budget winners

Let’s end on a high note, though. An unexpectedly high note. Some films don’t cost anything, compared to the money guzzlers we’ve been looking at but turn out to make hay.

Here are the 20 films with the lowest costs and the biggest margins recorded.
Let's have a look at how much they cost to make...
Nothing happened?
Let's try again. Here are their production budgets...
No?
Actually yes. But you can't see it on this scale (which is actually much tighter than what we've seen before). So one last (magnified) time...
There you go. Cute...
You can hover over them to see their budgets. El Mariachi cost $7000 US. That could’ve bought us 0.16 seconds of Avatar. Not 16 seconds, no no no: 0.16 seconds...
Here come their US revenues…
…and their worldwide total all-in revenue

…sorted by worldwide revenue.

I can’t claim to know all the films listed but if you want to make a low budget winner you should probably produce a Comedy. 7 of 20 low budget winners are of the light-hearted kind while we only had 1 in our previous loser's list.

But then of course... maybe a sequel of Deep Throat might be a worthy thought?

Thanks for sticking around...
